title: njschooldata Modernization Changes
text: File: R/cache.R Session-level caching downloaded data: Features: - -memory session cache hit/miss tracking - fetch_enr_cached() wrapper function - Cache statistics (items, memory usage, hit rate) - Enable/disable caching runtime
code: # Cached fetch - first call downloads, subsequent calls return cached data enr <- fetch_enr_cached(2024)      # Downloads enr <- fetch_enr_cached(2024)      # Returns cached (instant!)  # Cache management njsd_cache_info()    # Show cache stats njsd_cache_clear()   # Clear all cached data njsd_cache_list()    # List cached items njsd_cache_enable(FALSE)  # Disable caching  # Check cache status njsd_cache_enabled()

title: njschooldata Modernization Changes
text: File: R/progress.R Progress tracking batch downloads: Features: - Progress tracker item count, percentage, ETA - fetch_enr_years() multi-year enrollment - fetch_all_parcc_with_progress() detailed progress - Configurable enable/disable
code: # Fetch all years with progress enr_5yr <- fetch_enr_years(2020:2024)  # Shows progress  # Fetch all PARCC data with progress all_parcc <- fetch_all_parcc_with_progress()  # Control progress display njsd_progress_enable(FALSE)  # Quiet mode njsd_progress_enable(TRUE)   # Show progress

title: CLAUDE.md
text: njschooldata PUBLIC, OPEN SOURCE project. general-purpose infrastructure code belongs package (R/, tests/, etc.). Guidelines: - Code benefit user NJ school data → goes R/ - Code specific particular research question district → goes research-private/ - Helper functions created research general-purpose → refactor R/ - District-specific constants, analysis scripts, cached data → stay research-private/

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: njschooldata package provides simple interface accessing New Jersey Department Education (NJ DOE) school data R. NJ DOE publishes raw data files covering enrollment, assessments, graduation rates, - files use inconsistent formats across years, making longitudinal analysis challenging. package solves problem : Automatically downloading data NJ DOE servers Parsing various file formats (fixed-width, Excel, CSV) Standardizing column names across years Providing wide tidy data formats

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: Install package GitHub: Load package:
code: # Using remotes (recommended) remotes::install_github("almartin82/njschooldata")  # Or using devtools devtools::install_github("almartin82/njschooldata") library(njschooldata) library(dplyr)  # for data manipulation examples

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: functions use end_year specify school year. refers spring semester year:

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: New Jersey uses County-District-School (CDS) identifier system: county_id: 2-digit county code (e.g., “13” = Essex County) district_id: 4-digit district code school_id: 3-digit school code (“999” indicates district-level aggregate)
code: # A complete CDS code example: # County 13 (Essex), District 3570 (Newark), School 050 (specific school)

text: Data provided multiple aggregation levels, identified boolean flags:

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
code: # Get 2024 enrollment data (2023-24 school year) enr_2024 <- fetch_enr(2024)  # View the structure glimpse(enr_2024)  # Check dimensions dim(enr_2024)  # Rows and columns

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: tidy parameter transforms data easier analysis: tidy format better : - Comparing subgroups within schools - Longitudinal analysis across years - Filtering specific demographics
code: # Wide format (default) - one row per school, many demographic columns enr_wide <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = FALSE)  # Tidy format - one row per school-subgroup combination enr_tidy <- fetch_enr(2024, tidy = TRUE)

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
code: # Get only district-level totals district_totals <- enr_tidy %>%   filter(is_district, subgroup == "total_enrollment")  # Get only school-level data school_data <- enr_tidy %>%   filter(is_school)  # Get state totals state_totals <- enr_tidy %>%   filter(is_state)

title: Getting Started with njschooldata
text: Use fetch_parcc() NJSLA (2019+) PARCC (2015-2018) data: Note: 2020 assessments cancelled due COVID-19.
code: # Get 2024 Grade 4 Math results math_g4_2024 <- fetch_parcc(   end_year = 2024,   grade_or_subj = 4,   subj = "math" )  # Get 2024 Grade 8 ELA results ela_g8_2024 <- fetch_parcc(   end_year = 2024,   grade_or_subj = 8,   subj = "ela" )  # Get Algebra 1 results (high school) alg1_2024 <- fetch_parcc(   end_year = 2024,   grade_or_subj = "ALG1",   subj = "math" )

title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R
text: simple interface accessing NJ DOE school data R often said 80% data analysis spent process cleaning preparing data (Dasu Johnson 2003). Data preparation just first step, must repeated many course analysis new problems come light new data collected. -@hadley State NJ posting raw, fixed width text files assessment results NJ schools/districts well decade now. ’s great! Unfortunately, files bit pain work , especially ’re trying work multiple grades, multiple years data. Layouts change; file paths aren’t consistent, etc. njschooldata attempts simplify task working NJ education data providing concise consistent interface reading state files R. make heavy use tidyverse aim create consistent, pipeable interface NJ state education data.

title: A Simple Interface for Accessing NJ DOE School Data in R
text: NJ used several assessment systems years: NJASK (NJ Assessment Skills Knowledge): 2004-2014, Grades 3-8 HSPA (High School Proficiency Assessment): 2014, Grade 11 GEPA (Grade Eight Proficiency Assessment): 2007, Grade 8 PARCC: 2015-2018, aligned Common Core NJSLA (NJ Student Learning Assessment): 2019-present (2020 cancelled due COVID)

what: Add percentile rank columns for any metric — add_percentile_rank
title: Add percentile rank columns for any metric — add_percentile_rank
text: fundamental building block percentile rank calculations. Given grouped dataframe metric column, calculates percentile rank within group. Percentile rank defined percent comparison entities lesser equal performance. function respects existing grouping dataframe. want calculate percentile rank within specific peer groups (e.g., DFG, county), group data appropriately calling function, use define_peer_group() set grouping. Note: differs simpler percentile_rank(x, xo) util.R calculates percentile rank single value within vector. function operates dataframe columns adds rank/percentile columns.

title: Rank entities by achievement gap within peer group — gap_percentile_rank
text: df Output calculate_subgroup_gap() dataframe gap column gap_col Character. column containing gap values. Default "metric_gap". peer_type Character. Peer group type. See define_peer_group(). year_col Character. Year column name. Default "end_year". smaller_is_better Logical. TRUE (default), smaller gaps get higher percentile ranks. Set FALSE larger gaps preferred.

what: Track achievement gap trends over time — gap_trajectory

title: Track achievement gap trends over time — gap_trajectory

title: Track achievement gap trends over time — gap_trajectory
text: df Dataframe subgroups metrics multiple years metric_col Character. metric track. subgroup_a Character. Reference subgroup. subgroup_b Character. Comparison subgroup. year_col Character. Year column. Default "end_year". entity_cols Character vector. Columns identifying entity track.

title: Track achievement gap trends over time — gap_trajectory
text: df gap values trend columns: {metric}_gap_yoy_change: Year--year change gap {metric}_gap_cumulative_change: Change baseline year {metric}_gap_baseline: Gap value first year

title: Track achievement gap trends over time — gap_trajectory
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Track Newark's Black-White grad rate gap over time grate %>%   filter(district_id == "3570") %>%   gap_trajectory(     metric_col = "grad_rate",     subgroup_a = "white",     subgroup_b = "black"   ) } # }
